pros: Benefits and overall work life balance is strong. Work anywhere policy has made it possible for me to work from Chicago and Indiana. Team is really committed to the mission which makes my job more meaningful. Leader ship is open to new ideas and I feel energized by recent changes to my team and I’m excited about the future.
cons: There’s been a lot of change in the last 2 to 3 years which has made it difficult to get things done. We’ve lost some really talented managers and have not been able to replace them. We are navigating different times due to Covid.

pros: Flexible schedule. Remote. Great team.

pros: Great benefits and work/life balance.

review_title: A company in a state of significant instability
pros: The people. HIMSS is composed of extremely passionate individuals, each of who are extremely invested in propelling the quality of care delivery globally.
cons: HIMSS historically has and still continues to struggle to identify more diverse revenue sources outside of its in-person events. This has only been amplified by the pandemic and their need to pivot to more digitally focused engagements, which within their current infrastructure they’re incapable of supporting. Further compounding the issue is the organization’s limited breadth of experience. The majority of HIMSS employees have been tenured for more than ten years, resulting in highly proprietary knowledge, complacency, and worse, an inability to innovate. This is ironic, considering the company’s vision promotes “reform” for digital health. HIMSS has seen a significant amount of turnover—roughly 35% of its workforce left voluntarily in 2021. And, the small handful of layoffs, in early 2022, only dealt another damaging blow to the already distressed company. This, in part, is to blame on the c-suite’s inability to collectively agree upon and transparently communicate a roadmap for its product and services and a core set of priorities for the business. While HIMSS continues to ”reimagine” itself, determine how to pay its month's overdue bills, and its employees a fair market value, ambitious job seekers should take significant pause prior to actively considering a role here.

review_title: Very unstable company with lots of layoffs
pros: Easy work and Some interesting work
cons: Lots of layoffs and unplanned decisions

pros: They have great 401K matching.
cons: Do some industry research to match salaries better.

job_title: Facilities and Office Services Manager in Chicago, IL
pros:
Smart people who care about the culture and each other.
Beautiful offices in River North
Incredible HR professionals
cons: None so far! Very happy!

job_title: MRA At One Point in Chicago, IL
pros: The flexible work schedule was amazing, I appreciated the work/life balance. The pay was decent with great benefits like a 401K with 6% match and wonderful health insurance options. The training was comprehensive, my coworkers were a pleasure to work with, and the staff events were frequent.
cons:
Toxic management that will lie and backstab you - whatever is best for their bottom line. The one HR person who was genuinely helpful and kind is no longer there. Very few opportunities for advancement. Lack of communication. The massive layoffs in 2019 were handled horribly, termination letters were printed on a public printer where other employees found them. Those working in the office were corralled and let go like sheep, those working from home were let go with a brief phone call. If you appreciate transparency, desire loyalty and open communication, and hate feeling exploited or ignored, this is not the place for you. 

I put over a decade of my life into this company, and they crumpled me up like a piece of trash with one hand while handing me awards and certificates with the other. Hypocritical, unprofessional liars. The current CEO is a monster who refuses to learn his employees' names. The day of the mass layoffs, he bragged on a call about his private flight he had taken earlier. Absolutely no empathy or humanity, it's all about the almighty dollar. 

Just look at last year's conference, which had to be cancelled due to COVID - HIMSS had to settle a lawsuit because they weren't going to refund conference attendees or vendors. A health organization, and they're treating a pandemic as a cash grab? Not a good look.

cons: Work load, communication internally, and company organization

pros: Very good benefits like 6% 401K matching.

pros:
Great overall mission and team members. If you have the right manager there can be a lot of room for growth.

Match 100% on up to 6% salary contribution to 401k after 6 months of employment.

There is a lot of change and restructuring going on at the moment. In the long run I believe it will be good for the organization but there are a lot of growing pains in the meantime.
cons:
Work from home policy is almost too flexible - some team members you will see at most once a year and the office is often mostly empty because even those with desks are almost never there.

Only start with 2 weeks of vacation/year accrued unless you are a Director or higher, very strict about accrual policies and cannot go negative.

pros: salary & benefits. Co-workers are intelligent and committed to their work.
cons: The culture is suffocating and limiting. Alcoholism is accepted and promoted at almost every off-site event. Misogyny is rampant and on display at group functions that involve alcohol. Reminder to management: It's not o.k. to make racist comments while black female employees are at the dinner table. (and BTW, I'm white.) Senior management is ill-equipped to lead. Great ideas get crushed by poor planning and poor deployment.

pros: Flexible work schedule. Many opportunities to travel on the job if you are on the right job. Very collaborative teams/departments within the company. Many opportunities to gain experience/skills as a young professional.
cons: Challenging onboarding and training process. Staff resources are minimal / expectations high. Unplanned mission critical projects are often thrown on your plate to accomplish with no additional support. Poor middle managment.  Company does not promote individuals in thier current role. You must request to have your job description rewritten and graded by an outside agency (which is not easy to do) or jump to another position in the company. Specific career path is not clear for individuals.

pros: If you like putting conferences together- job descriptions are nothing like what you are expected to do.
cons: Extremely difficult to communicate with management - Revolving door as far as employees go.  They do not want honesty...they just not talk about the problems - how can on solve a problem if they do not even acknowledge it exists -they want blind followers who say ok to everything and they definitely do not like change (focusing on technology for healthcare???).

review_title: Professional and career growth if you adapt
pros:
Evolving as a business through diversification of products and services to health and technology market
Audience, digital and data first approach to new product development in media division
Great coworkers 
If you embrace change and are adaptable, plentiful opportunity to grow professionally
cons: Not everyone has embraced the changes, new opportunities and structure, which slows down growth and advancement.

pros: Flexible working environment - work from home full-time.  After working there for 10 years 5 weeks of vacation.
cons: No room for growth.  Most departments are either top heavy so you can't go from assistant to Manager easily or if you are a Manager it's extremely difficult to become a Director.

review_title: Poor management, high turnover, toxic culture
pros: Benefits package (although that progressively worsened for Maine-based staff). Pay may be adequate for senior level positions.
cons: High turnover for the Media arm. Management, all offsite in various locations,  is top heavy, disorganized, poor at communicating, and overstaffed with former consultants/gurus who are not trained or capable leaders of people and are instead focused on retaining/advancing their own positions and ideas, minimally invested in those they manage. Growth within the company is highly restrictive and often political, and even if you do climb up somehow HR will delay your pay increase for months if they can get away with it.  Preference given to outsiders for new positions. HR relies far too heavily on a clunky and overwrought grading system called Halogen which it doesn’t even train the managers on, making an already grievous process of reducing employee success to a flawed, uncompromising rating scale even worse with user error. Of course, when a manager messes up, they can get away with it. HR also never implements a transition plan, so when employees in unique and critical roles inevitably storm out the door, they take all their experience and knowledge and process with them leaving the rest of the team to pick up the pieces. This often disrupts the business in various departments. The company spends so much time recovering from the high turnover that it creates even more turnover from the stress incurred by not preparing for the same scenario over and over again. The Maine office, once a thriving hub of almost 50 employees has been reduced to a dozen(ish) and is closing at the end of this month. The culture there got progressively worse because the EVP was reluctant to lead people and address anything other than the bottom line. Too bad, when the Media arm was an independent startup, it was a great place to work. HIMSS ruined it.

pros: If you come from the corporate world, its easy to make a name for yourself as most employees are from the association world which is naturally less competitive and complacent. Your colleagues will most likely be awesome.
cons: Extremely clicky, almost like high school. There are the originals who think they are better than everyone because they have been around since it was a small hospital association. There are the media folks who have a chip on their shoulder and think they know it all (this dept actually was created when HIMSS CEO bought a failing digital media company focused on healthcare - Medtech Media) even though until recently have drained more money than they have put back in and have a history unscrupulous business practices. HIMSS Analytics is like the red-headed step child which actually makes money but (until recent downsizing - finally!) had a call center of 30 entry level FTE's, 3 managers and a director all for the sake of collecting hospital information. The problem was most of the callers lacked basic experience in an office environment and were incapable or unwilling to do their jobs and do them well. about a 3rd of this workforce (with quality staff) could accomplish the same load of work with higher accuracy significantly reducing the divisions overhead. Luckily, the EVP of this team knows what he's doing and has taken such steps among many other improvements ( i guess this piece belongs under the pro's?). Lastly there are the outcasts such as mHealth and Hx360 purchased and created by HIMSS but have yet to find their calling and no longer being "the others" of the organization. Executive Management works together about as well as a group of prepubescent children on a book report.

pros:
